articles.headline: To Back Democracy, U.S. Prepares to Cut $1 Billion From Egypt’s Debt
articles.snippet: Nearly 16 months after first pledging to help Egypt’s failing economy, the Obama administration is nearing an agreement with the country’s new government to relieve $1 billion of its debt.
articles.abstract: Nearly 16 months after first pledging to help Egypt’s failing economy, the Obama administration is nearing an agreement with the country’s new government to relieve $1 billion of its debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 16 months after first pledging to help Egypt’s failing economy, the Obama administration is nearing an agreement with the country’s new government to relieve $1 billion of its debt as part of an American and international assistance package intended to bolster its transition to democracy, administration officials said.

articles.headline: Crops in India Wilt in a Weak Monsoon Season
articles.snippet: With the nourishing downpours of the monsoon season down an average of 12 percent across India, farmers are on the brink of disaster.
articles.abstract: With the nourishing downpours of the monsoon season down an average of 12 percent across India, farmers are on the brink of disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: MURUMA, India — Vilas Dinkar Mukane lives halfway around the world from the corn farmers of Iowa, but the Indian sharecropper is at risk of losing his livelihood for the same reason: not enough rain.

articles.headline: How Plan to Help City Pay Pensions Backfired
articles.snippet: A bond sale that was intended to help Stockton, Calif., reduce a shortfall in pension money wound up making the problem worse.
articles.abstract: A bond sale that was intended to help Stockton, Calif., reduce a shortfall in pension money wound up making the problem worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey A. Michael, a finance professor in Stockton, Calif., took a hard look at his city’s bankruptcy this summer and thought he saw a smoking gun: a dubious bond deal that bankers had pushed on Stockton just as the local economy was starting to tank in the spring of 2007, he said.

articles.headline: Fears Rising, Spaniards Pull Out Their Cash and Get Out of Spain
articles.snippet: While the situation in Spain is not as dire as that of Greece, some Spaniards are taking their euros, and sometimes themselves and their families, out of the country.
articles.abstract: While the situation in Spain is not as dire as that of Greece, some Spaniards are taking their euros, and sometimes themselves and their families, out of the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is, Julio Vildosola concedes, a very big bet.

articles.headline: Foreign Firms Most Affected by a U.S. Law Barring Bribes
articles.snippet: A law intended to prohibit bribery of foreign officials by United States businesses has led to more than $3 billion in settlements, but nine of the top 10 were with foreign companies.
articles.abstract: A law intended to prohibit bribery of foreign officials by United States businesses has led to more than $3 billion in settlements, but nine of the top 10 were with foreign companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: A law intended to prohibit the payment of bribes to foreign officials by United States businesses has produced more than $3 billion in settlements. But a list of the top companies making these settlements is notable in one respect: its lack of American names.

articles.headline: Democrats Say U.S. Is Better Off Than Four Years Ago
articles.snippet: The party’s message to wavering voters is that President Obama was the right choice in 2008, and that he has the country on its way to a sustainable recovery.
articles.abstract: The party’s message to wavering voters is that President Obama was the right choice in 2008, and that he has the country on its way to a sustainable recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — A day after fumbling a predictable and straightforward question posed by Mitt Romney last week — are Americans better off than they were four years ago — the Obama campaign provided a response on Monday that it said would be hammered home during the Democratic convention here this week: “Absolutely.”

articles.headline: Elephants Dying in Epic Frenzy as Ivory Fuels Wars and Profits
articles.snippet: Conservation groups say poachers are wiping out tens of thousands of elephants a year, more than at any time in the previous two decades, with the ivory trade becoming increasingly militarized.
articles.abstract: Conservation groups say poachers are wiping out tens of thousands of elephants a year, more than at any time in the previous two decades, with the ivory trade becoming increasingly militarized.
articles.lead_paragraph: GARAMBA NATIONAL PARK, Democratic Republic of Congo — In 30 years of fighting poachers, Paul Onyango had never seen anything like this. Twenty-two dead elephants, including several very young ones, clumped together on the open savanna, many killed by a single bullet to the top of the head.

articles.headline: Spirit of ’08 Gone, Democrats Reunite Against G.O.P. Threat
articles.snippet: The party is not as united as it was four years ago, but Democrats are finding common purpose in denying Republicans control of the White House and Congress next year.
articles.abstract: The party is not as united as it was four years ago, but Democrats are finding common purpose in denying Republicans control of the White House and Congress next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Four years ago, Barack Obama accepted the presidential nomination of a Democratic Party that was as unified and energized as at any moment in its past: Clintons and Kennedys, labor and Wall Street, centrists and leftists, old and young, blacks, whites and Hispanics. It bristled with the excitement of history and the expectations of a new era.

articles.headline: Gas Prices Rise, but So Do Auto Sales
articles.snippet: Analysts said a wide range of fuel-efficient models, particularly from Detroit automakers, has helped spur demand and accelerate the industry’s recovery.
articles.abstract: Analysts said a wide range of fuel-efficient models, particularly from Detroit automakers, has helped spur demand and accelerate the industry’s recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In the past, nothing slowed down strong car sales faster than a spike in gasoline prices.

articles.headline: Family Life According to the Brotherhood
articles.snippet: Egypt’s Muslim Brotherhood is committed to upholding patriarchal and traditional values around a woman’s place in society, and many Egyptian women need no convincing.
articles.abstract: Egypt’s Muslim Brotherhood is committed to upholding patriarchal and traditional values around a woman’s place in society, and many Egyptian women need no convincing.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Women are erratic and emotional, and they make good wives and mothers — but never leaders or rulers. That, at least, is what Osama Abou Salama, a professor of botany at Cairo University and a member of the Muslim Brotherhood, told young men and women during a recent premarital counseling class.

articles.headline: New Editor at Cosmopolitan: Joanna Coles Replaces Kate White
articles.snippet: The appointment of Joanna Coles installs new leadership at a publication that has evolved from a general interest and literary magazine to an aspirational companion for young women, covering fashion, relationships and, more recently, careers.
articles.abstract: The appointment of Joanna Coles installs new leadership at a publication that has evolved from a general interest and literary magazine to an aspirational companion for young women, covering fashion, relationships and, more recently, careers.
articles.byline: By David Carr and Christine Haughney
